f6_assessments.q0:
The challenge is well stated. The solution proposed - Employment Contract Dapp is possible to remedy the problem but some kind of background legal enforcement should be in place before that. 
The lack of formal work contracts bad practice is unlikely to be changed if simply a new type of digital contract is introduced as an option. The unwillingness of employees/employers to sign a paper work contract wont change if there is a new digital contract type to sign because they are unwilling to do it in first place.
However - even the largest problems can be started to be tackled step by step. So - the Dapp idea can be a first stage in that process if it is accepted in at least 2 or 3 local employers.
I would suggest the proposal to be changed after initial talks are being made with some employers that are willing to accept such an approach for electronic contracts. This would allow the smart contract to be customized to the specific needs and include for example the "payment when work-hours are fulfilled" or "payment after delivery of goods", which are very progressive ideas in principle!
I would give 4 stars "Agree" to the impact assessment recognizing that if such a Dapp works in small scale (2-3 companies) it can work for the whole world.
f6_assessments.q2:
The timeline of the project implementation consists of 3 months, 6 months and 12 months from the start, but these describe the deliverables, not KPIs that can be used to keep track on the progress. Since it is a Dapp development proposal - it maybe needs a way to shown the progress of the code written.
Unfortunately here I would also disagree that the information is sufficient for the progress to be auditable.
f6_assessments.reply: The Feasibility Note is well-written and constructive, but it fundamentally misunderstands that the proposal only concerns funds for further research, as is clearly outlined in the budget section. Similarly, it is clear from the Auditability Note that the timeline has been misunderstood. The timeline is does not refer to what is expected to be achieved from the money received in fund6. However, it is understandable that this is their interpretation (given that all other proposals are using the timeline in this way). I should've been much more clear on this point and perhaps not even included a long-term timeline even if doing so was recommended in the proposals guide.

f6_assessments.q0: This project will improve options for both employers and employees and enable the shifting of the power dynamics in the new ways of work hence minimising exploitation.
f6_assessments.q1: Very passionate experienced team, however for the success of the entire venture, the team needs to expand in diversity and size to allow for new ideas and innovations to make it long term for the changing market needs.
f6_assessments.q2: The project does not have enough documentation and information access for the community to follow and support it.
